{"abstract": "The styles of the two investors could not be more different. But Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews notes that both men beat the market by betting on America, playing hardball and trading on personal brands.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/03/03/buffett-and-icahn-birds-of-a-feather/", "snippet": "The styles of the two investors could not be more different. But Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews notes that both men beat the market by betting on America, playing hardball and trading on personal brands.", "lead_paragraph": "Warren E. \u00a0Buffett and Carl C. Icahn are inverse investors who correlate in more ways than one. In recently released letters to shareholders, the two billionaires talk up their returns and approaches to deploying capital. Their styles couldn\u2019t be more different, but both beat the market by betting on America, playing hardball and trading on personal brands. Yet their greatest common bond is that neither can be easily replicated.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Buffett and Icahn: Birds of a Feather?", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Shareholder Rights and Activism", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Buffett, Warren E", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Icahn, Carl C", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Berkshire Hathaway Inc", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-03-03T19:38:25+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Jeffrey Goldfarb", "person": [{"firstname": "Jeffrey", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Goldfarb", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/ab5f1308-3287-520f-af5d-7df3513b20eb", "word_count": 441, "uri": "nyt://article/ab5f1308-3287-520f-af5d-7df3513b20eb"}

TAKES AIM AT 10TH FORMER SAC EMPLOYEE \u00a0|\u00a0 The Securities and Exchange Commission\u2019s investigation into Steven A. Cohen\u2019s hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, isn\u2019t done just yet. Federal regulators announced on Thursday a civil case against Ronald N. Dennis, who worked for SAC for less than two years, for prompting a number of illegal trades stemming from confidential tips he received about two technology companies, Dell and Foundry Networks, Ben Protess and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. Mr. Dennis, the 10th former employee of SAC to face civil or criminal insider trading charges, settled with the S.E.C., agreeing to be banned from the securities industry and to pay $200,000.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "S.E.C. In a letter to Howard R. Levine, Family Dollar\u2019s chief executive, Mr. Icahn urged the company to self itself \u201cimmediately.\u201d He also demanded that three of his representatives be added to Family Dollar\u2019s board. {"abstract": "Banks eager to work with Apple on new mobile payment system. | Signs rattle subprime lending industry. | Bankers fear Britain\u2019s exit from E.U. | Hertz and Icahn make peace.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/09/12/morning-agenda-banks-bow-to-apple-pay/", "snippet": "Banks eager to work with Apple on new mobile payment system. | Signs rattle subprime lending industry. | Bankers fear Britain\u2019s exit from E.U. | Hertz and Icahn make peace.", "lead_paragraph": "BANKS BOW TO APPLE PAY | As Apple looks to assume a more central role in the financial universe with its new payment system, Apple Pay, the eagerness of banks and credit card companies to work with the technology giant underscores both its influence and the recognition among financial institutions that they face bigger challenges from upstart technology ventures, DealBook\u2019s Nathaniel Popper writes. Apple Pay could threaten some revenue streams, but the banking industry appears willing to invest in programs like Apple\u2019s that still respect the traditional financial system.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Banks Bow to Apple Pay", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-09-12T11:20:29+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/c3c706c0-e79c-5556-9ec7-13e73468266c", "word_count": 2234, "uri": "nyt://article/c3c706c0-e79c-5556-9ec7-13e73468266c"}

{"abstract": "While activists have been criticized for short-term \u201cquarterly capitalism,\u201d they may hold shares longer than many institutional or retail investors.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/05/business/dealbook/headlines-aside-some-activist-investors-take-the-long-view.html", "snippet": "While activists have been criticized for short-term \u201cquarterly capitalism,\u201d they may hold shares longer than many institutional or retail investors.", "lead_paragraph": "Are activist investors short-term traders or in it for the long term? It is the question of the moment as nearly $200 billion has poured into the coffers of activists with names like Icahn, Ackman and Peltz, among others. Last year, as a group they put some 200 companies in their cross hairs and replaced 19 chief executives, according to the law firm Sidley Austin, putting pressure on virtually every board in the {"abstract": "Starboard Value has asked Rockwell Collins to consider selling itself instead of buying B/E Aerospace. The hedge fund faces an uphill climb.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/01/business/dealbook/activist-fund-has-tough-sell-to-get-rockwell-to-rethink-deal.html", "snippet": "Starboard Value has asked Rockwell Collins to consider selling itself instead of buying B/E Aerospace. The hedge fund faces an uphill climb.", "lead_paragraph": "Starboard Value is flying close to the sun. Starboard, the activist hedge fund run by Jeff Smith, wants aircraft-parts maker Rockwell Collins to consider ditching a $6.4 billion tie-up with B/E Aerospace. Grounding the merger has merit, but Carl Icahn and others have had mixed results agitating against mergers and acquisitions. A Trump-inspired rally in Rockwell\u2019s stock complicates Starboard\u2019s case.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Activist Fund Has Tough Sell to Get Rockwell to Rethink Deal", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "BE Aerospace Inc", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Starboard Value LP", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Icahn, Carl C", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2016-12-01T21:59:20+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Kevin Allison", "person": [{"firstname": "Kevin", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Allison", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/61d01070-bdfa-5ad7-a825-a5a50046287d", "word_count": 368, "uri": "nyt://article/61d01070-bdfa-5ad7-a825-a5a50046287d"}

{"abstract": "Kathryn Marinello becomes chief facing missed third-quarter estimates and a cut in the company\u2019s full-year guidance.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/14/business/dealbook/new-hertz-chief-faces-a-tough-road.html", "snippet": "Kathryn Marinello becomes chief facing missed third-quarter estimates and a cut in the company\u2019s full-year guidance.", "lead_paragraph": "The new Hertz Global chief executive, Kathryn Marinello, faces a tough drive out of the ditch. She has a great r\u00e9sum\u00e9. The problem is that she is the $2 billion rental car outfit\u2019s third boss in two years \u2014 and the activist investor Carl C. Icahn is in the back seat, fidgeting with a 35 percent stake. Moreover, the company\u2019s engine is sputtering, despite her predecessor\u2019s attempts to get it firing more smoothly.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "New Hertz Chief Faces a Tough Road", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Careers and Professions", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Appointments and Executive Changes", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Hertz Global Holdings Inc", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Marinello, Kathryn V", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2016-12-14T22:22:05+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Antony Currie", "person": [{"firstname": "Antony", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Currie", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a2919445-6cbc-5649-8d42-ea490e50137a", "word_count": 385, "uri": "nyt://article/a2919445-6cbc-5649-8d42-ea490e50137a"}
